ratings.question_text: What is your overall assessment of this course?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 for a fellow student? Would you recommend AFAM 505 01/AMST 643 01 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: A great class if you are interested in poetry, humanities, different perspectives and personal growth.

I'd certainly recommend it if they have an interest in poetry generally, waka specifically, or literary theory. Or, alternatively, if they are simply studying some form of Japanese culture that intimately involves poetry.

narratives.question_text: How did this course deepen your knowledge of your discipline/profession? To what extent did this course contribute to your dissertation/research?
comments: Waka is a mode of speech that is constantly deployed in virtually any major art form up until the modern era and even there, it is ever-present in the works of certain individuals. Thus, while I have no desire to study waka or poetry more broadly in any serious capacity, the knowledge I obtained in this class on 'what' the poem is and how it operates will be invaluable when understanding how it works when it appears in the context of a different art form (prose, theatre, etc).
This course perfectly suited my interest in the intersection of poetics and religion/spirituality.
